data.text:
@robertson_lab @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine ah, yes.
give ed more money so he can photograph the next animal at the next nondescript market across the street from the next SARS lab that will nuke all their data. pay him more to call us conspiracy theorists for asking to see entirely redacted conversations on burner phones. https://t.co/qya8yFqCGN
@robertson_lab @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine What lessons did we learn from Covid-19? We still don't know its origins. Quit with the group think junk science.

@robertson_lab @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine One would think the discovery of a novel SARSr-CoV in pangolin and Malayan porcupine datasets would be an important finding to discuss, yet @edwardcholmes doesn't mention it https://t.co/jttWUpuThR
@robertson_lab @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine And this has nothing to do with the WIV.

@robertson_lab @K_G_Andersen @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine I really hope the guy in the video is wrong about what he is saying. If he is right, all trust in the experts will be lost. https://t.co/RAbDnUbBbz
@robertson_lab @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine Ok sure, but not SARS-CoV2, with its patented furin cleavage site and HIV nucleotides.
@WichroDr @robertson_lab @K_G_Andersen @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine More appropriate, "What could we have learned?".

@robertson_lab @K_G_Andersen @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine Crisis is the accumulation of small things being neglected over time. Any action and lack of such does impact planetary health, the base of human life. What did we learn from COVID-19?

@robertson_lab @edwardcholmes @ScienceMagazine "increasingly porous humanâ€“animal interface" LOL. You mean as GOF scientists have increasingly inserted designer FCS's into dangerous animal/synthetic viruses adapting them for humans and then aerosolizing them. @Ayjchan @R_H_Ebright @BillyBostickson @JamieMetzl @FilippaLentzos
